block.p: Tentative Najaf Agreement After a Day of Bloodshed Aides to Iraq's most powerful Shiite leader, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, said they had reached a tentative agreement to end the siege in Najaf, following a day of chaos and bloodshed that left at least 74 Iraqis dead and more than 300 wounded.

Classified parts of the report by three Army generals on the abuses at Abu Ghraib prison say Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, the former top commander in Iraq, approved the use of some severe interrogation practices intended to be limited to captives held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and Afghanistan.

Medical ethicists and the Army itself said that the failures of Army medical staff to prevent and report torture at Abu Ghraib prison shows the need for more investigation and better training.

Former Chilean Dictator's Case Chile's Supreme Court stripped the former dictator Augusto Pinochet of immunity from prosecution, raising hopes of victims that he may finally face trial for abuses during his 17-year rule. The ruling is the latest decision in cases that accuse him of ordering to kidnap, torture and kill leftists.

Clean Water Problems in Africa Sub-Saharan Africa is lagging far behind the rest of the developing world in access to clean water, with more than 4 out of 10 people still relying on rivers, ponds or other unsafe sources of drinking water, according to a United Nations report. The report blamed conflict, political instability, population growth and the low priority that is given to water and sanitation.

Little Progress in Russia Query The flight recorders of the two crashed Russian airliners were damaged and could provide little help in determining the cause of the twin disasters, which killed at least 89 people. On what was an official day of mourning in Russia, officials continued to offer incomplete and, at times, contradictory statements about what happened.

Bush Declines to Condemn Ads on Kerry's War Record President Bush said he did not believe Senator John Kerry lied about his war record, but he declined to condemn the commercial paid for by a veterans group contending that Mr. Kerry came by his medals dishonestly.
Census Shows Growth of Poor The number of people in poverty grew in 2003 for the third straight year, the government reported, in a sign of a long slump in the job markets.
The number of people without health insurance rose 1.4 million, to a record 45 million last year.
Seizing on the census report, Senator John Kerry challenged the president to weekly debates until Election Day.

Strengthening Intelligence Role President Bush is preparing to issue an executive order that would designate the director of central intelligence to fill much of the role envisioned for a future national intelligence director, officials who have been briefed on the plan said.

Suspect Says He's in Al Qaeda A 36-year-old Yemeni on trial at Guantánamo Bay for conspiracy to commit terrorism said he was a member of Al Qaeda and if he were not allowed to represent himself he would boycott the trial.

Ruling Against Abortion Ban A federal judge ruled that a law banning a rarely used method of abortion was unconstitutional because it did not exempt cases where the procedure might be necessary to protect a woman's health.
Problem With Flu Vaccine A manufacturer of influenza vaccine detected a contamination problem in its new vaccine supply and delayed the release of 50 million doses.
New Yorkers Are Uneasy As Convention Week Nears Half of all New Yorkers are awaiting the Republican National Convention with a mix of dread and unease, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

Protesters offered a preview of what delegates may expect when they arrive this weekend: spontaneous acts at high-profile locations meant to draw maximum attention. At least 21 people were arrested at three events in Manhattan.
The convention has triggered an intense reaction among New York artists, as political fervor is being translated into painting, sculpture, Web art and political ephemera.

69 People Linked to Drug Ring Sixty-nine people, most of them members of five closely linked families, were accused of cooperating as one narcotics trafficker by peddling heroin and cocaine in Brooklyn housing projects, prosecutors said.
U.S. Women Win Soccer Gold The United States beat Brazil in overtime, 2-1, to win the gold medal in women's soccer.
China Gains as Olympic Power China is running a close second to the United States in the medal count. The country's success remains largely confined to individual sports.

Old Subsidies Collected Student loan corporations are taking advantage of a loophole in the law, billing the federal government nearly $1 billion a year for a subsidy that was supposed to have faded away, government data show.

Criminal Activity on the Web The Justice Department announced that more than 150 people had been arrested, charged or convicted in the last three months in a wide-ranging sweep of criminal activity on the Internet.

Van Safety Underscored Federal crash statistics show that there were 11.2 deaths for every 100,000 registered vans last year, with 16.42 deaths in sport utility vehicles, 14.85 in passenger cars and 15.17 in pickup trucks.
Editorials: Abu Ghraib, the next step; warming to global warming; Sunday in the park; warm and fuzzy Olympians.
